4 out of 5 stars

First time played and completed was in 2020 (pandemic game).

After 200 more hours, I finished My Time at Portia again, and thanks to my ADHD-addled brain forgetting everything, it was like a whole new story to me. lol Did I remember Huss & Tuss? Ursula? The Rogue Knight? The All-Source? Defeating the Rats? Nope, not a memory in my head but "Ugh, why did I marry Gust?" Rest assured, he didn't get the Husband treatment this time around (Mint did, however).

Portia is, unfortunately, leagues behind Sandrock. Pathea really took everything we loved about Portia, and left behind everything we hated, for Sandrock. But it's still worth playing, if just to understand the easter eggs in Sandrock (my memory of this game was so bad, Owen mentioned he met 7 brothers and I didn't even remember the Hulu brothers of Portia. How does someone forget THEM?).

There are a lot of little issues that add up; voice lines unvoiced, wrong dialogue being said, some quests leading no where. And boy howdy, the controls and main gameplay are hard to get used to after Sandrock.

But it's still got charm, a great story, interesting characters and is generally fun to play. I played this second time because I wanted to remember the whole story in preparation for My Time at Evershine, the third game in the franchise. I love the whole story of Duvos vs The Alliance/Ethea, the Day of Calamity, everything - it's fascinating.

I don't know if I'll ever play a third time; hopefully the memory of the story sticks from this playthrough. lol But I'm glad I played it again, and honestly, I can enjoy Sandrock even more now that I understand the Portia easter eggs. A win win!

Love it. 
Its a great combination of survival crafting, farming cozy life, and light dungeon delving. The story development is minor but it is engaging enough to keep me playing after I've made the best furnaces and axe, etc. Only to discover I didn't have the best furnace anyway.  
Some minor quality of life issues with menus and storage, but I have a pen and paper next to me so I make it work.
I recommend playing with character voices off, they are pretty cringe and take me out of the game.

I didn't really expect to like this game at first, if I'm being perfectly honest. I grabbed it while it was on sale for really cheap, and figured it'd be something nice to try in between other games. But I honestly got pretty sucked into this game right away, and enjoyed myself quite a lot! 

I really liked the town, the world, and exploring new areas. I also loved the mining, and enjoyed how interactive the events in game were. The crafting and machines could be a little awkward to manage at times, but felt pretty rewarding, and I especially liked filling out the museum.

I think that the biggest drawback for this game is absolutely the graphics, unfortunately. I like the vibrant colors, and the environments are nice, but the stylization of the people and animals is... something I'm not a fan of. The horse in particular, with its noodle legs, was one of my least favorite models to look at.

I also was a bit frustrated by how limited decorating the house felt. I really liked that decorating the house provided buffs, though!

I actually wound up buying Sandrock while playing this game, and I kind of had to force myself to finish the main storyline in Portia because I was too excited to try out Sandrock hahaha. I definitely recommend finishing Portia first before Sandrock, if you have an interest in the series. The graphics in Sandrock are much prettier, and there are a lot of quality of life features added to it that I think would make playing the games in reverse frustrating.

I bought a few games in a Steam sale recently and this was one of them.  I chose this game because it (and its sequel) had been positively talked about in a facebook cosy game group I am a member of and the price was right (less than $10 AU).  Clicking the buy button was a no brainer.  

It is a relatively old game (released in 2019 and I am playing it for the first time at the end of 2025), but it has been worth every penny and it has held up surprisingly well after 6 years.  I am impressed.  Steam says I have 81 hours at the time of writing this.  I don't.  I think a few times I had logged out to the main menu and walked away.  I would say easily 40 hours though and I don't regret a minute I have spent and have thoroughly enjoyed my time in Portia.  I have only hit the end of year 1 and there is still so much to do with 61 achievements remaining.

There is so much to do and so many characters to meet and it is like Stardew, but also uniquely its own with the dystopian back story.  There is mining, farming, construction, romancing townies, quests, fighting...it has it all.  And for someone who is a bit uncoordinated with the fighting, the battles are super easy and if you die, you restart without losing anything (thank you!).

I look forward to trying out the sequel (My time at  Sandrock), but I am glad I started at this one first.  Now my only question is who do I romance.  I think I am leaning towards Arlo....wish me luck!

At the start of the pandemic, when I was cooped up in my house, I finally decided to try this game after having it sit on my wishlist for ages.  For better and for worse, I became addicted as it slowly took over my time.  It didnâ€™t matter if I was doing quests, producing items, rearranging my farm, gathering resources, building relationships, or diving into everyoneâ€™s stories - I was fully immersed.  I even made it my goal to never reset the mine and clear it out into one giant empty cube.  Spoiler: [spoiler]that never happened.[/spoiler]

However, as real life went on, the pandemic waned, and the world started returning to normal, this life-sim became less [i]life-sim[/i] and more [i]sim[/i].  I started looking at it objectively.  To avoid starting over, my one save turned into a fever dream of marital chaos - getting married, having two kids, getting divorced, and then remarrying everyone tied to an achievement.  Not just the women, but the men too.  It was messy, dramatic, and kind of hilarious.  I was genuinely heartbroken watching my first love walk away after I divorced her for an achievementâ€¦ but by the end, I was numb to love, marriage, and divorce alike - just laughing at the absurdity of it all.  I donâ€™t think my kids are doing alright though.

Now, one caveat to my recommendation: I have a theory that the first life-sim you play will always be the best one to you.  And this was my first.

I LOVE this game. 

While this is supposed to be a "play at your own pace" kind of game... It's not. You only get so many hours (minutes) each day, and even when you adjust game speed, you still have to plan ahead by days or even weeks, in order not to miss anything. Each day seems like a rush to get things done until near the end of the game. You also can't just save. Your game only saves at the end of each day, so make a mistake at the end of the day and need to start over, and you start the entire day over. 

The characters are really amazing, and I have played it through several times. My first play through I picked Ginger as a wife sort of at random. Then I learned her back story, and she was so relatable, I never went with another romantic partner in any other play through. Small spoilers here, so skip to the next paragraph if you don't want to know. Ginger is sick, and can't be in the light very much. There is an event each year where gifts are dropped from a balloon and everyone tries to grab them. Even though I had max reputation with Ginger, I realized that she could not participate. So I got her gifts. That is how much I liked the character. I felt bad for her, and wanted to make this make believe person happy. That is because her story is done so well. 

Other characters are going to appeal to different people. I think there is probably someone for everyone, and their stories are fantastic. 

People complain about the fighting mechanics, but I never had an issue with it. 

I like to build things, and build up a base without having to fight things off in some sort of war, so this was great, as you start with a tiny plot of land and grow it to be huge and filled with things. However, you are in competition with another builder, so there is a drive to do it better faster, without fear of losing what you have built. 

Overall I love this game, and recommend it to anyone who enjoys this kind of game.

My Time at Portia is one of those games I didnâ€™t expect to fall in love with, but ended up sinking hours into without even realizing it. If you're not a hardcore gamer or just want something low-stress to relax with after work or school, this game really hits the spot. It doesn't rush you, there's no pressure to "win," and the world is just genuinely enjoyable to spend time in.

The best way I can describe it is cozy. You wake up in your workshop, check your commissions, maybe tend to your farm, explore some ruins, or just stroll around talking to the locals. The pace is completely up to you, and thereâ€™s something super satisfying about slowly upgrading your home, building machines, and watching the town respond to your progress. Even simple tasks like gathering wood or decorating your space feel rewarding over time.

What really kept me coming back, though, were the characters and the atmosphere. The people in Portia have their own routines, personalities, and little story arcs that you can get involved in at your own pace. It makes the world feel alive without being overwhelming. Plus, the soundtrack and visuals are really calmingâ€”perfect for when you just want to zone out and de-stress.

If you're looking for something chill, creative, and full of charm, My Time at Portia is 100% worth checking out. It's not trying to be the biggest or most complex game out there, but that's exactly why it's so good.

[b]Tentative Recommendation[/b]

Farming & crafting game set (surprisingly) in a post-post apocalyptic world.

Explore the surrounding countryside to collect resources, go mining for ores and treasures, and go to NPCs in town or the commissions board for quests or crafting jobs to fulfil.

Crafting is done by building machines on your farm to refine resources into components, which are then assembled manually into products according to blueprints you unlock over the course of the game. The machines take time to do their thing, so time management is a must here. 

So far, so good. Nothing groundbreaking obviously, but most of whatâ€™s on offer here is perfectly fine.

The problem with My Time at Portia, though, is the other part of the game -- specifically, the dungeon crawling part. Because itâ€™sâ€¦ not great, to say the least. The combat is extremely barebones, the enemy variety is extremely sparse, and the dungeons you can delve are boring, short, and almost without exception procedurally generated. This is only exacerbated by the fact that theyâ€™re full of important crafting components you canâ€™t get elsewhere, so youâ€™ll likely have spent hours farming in them before the end of the game.

Decent fun overall, but not particularly memorable.

The best way I can describe it is cozy. You wake up in your workshop, check your commissions, maybe tend to your farm, explore some ruins, or just stroll around talking to the locals. The pace is completely up to you, and thereâ€™s something super satisfying about slowly upgrading your home, building machines, and watching the town respond to your progress. Even simple tasks like gathering wood or decorating your space feel rewarding over time.

What really kept me coming back, though, were the characters and the atmosphere. The people in Portia have their own routines, personalities, and little story arcs that you can get involved in at your own pace. It makes the world feel alive without being overwhelming. Plus, the soundtrack and visuals are really calmingâ€”perfect for when you just want to zone out and de-stress.

If you're looking for something chill, creative, and full of charm, My Time at Portia is 100% worth checking out. It's not trying to be the biggest or most complex game out there, but that's exactly why it's so good.

Very entertaining, super nice and cozy! I just can't stop playing!

Bad design, and I do *not* have patience for it.

My Time at Portia (MTaP) looks like Stardew Valley (SV), but it is kind of not. SV is relaxing and you do what you want each day pretty much, MTaP has leaderboards and many timed events that require your constant attention. SV also has a major farming element while in MTaP has a factory farm which is much less fun.

Overall, MTaP is simply not that fun. It looks like the devs just had a list of "features" and called it quits after the list was done. Many mechanics are not fun at all (ie, the dates). You also waste tons of time just waiting around for things to start. 

I would recommend achievement hunters skip this game. Not only are many RNG and not fun (ie, picking up 500 poop, winning rock paper scissors, etc), but you need to do a whole bunch of romance quests with both genders. Totally immersion breaking regardless of which way you swing.

Redeeming features is that the game looks pretty nice and is relatively bug free. Overall, 5/10.
The crafting recipes are quite difficult, and require building more and more machines just to keep up.

Do you know what's better than inventory management, coming back from a day running around all over the place and the game crashes in the inventory management screen and you get reset back to the start of the day.

It's going to be a no from me. I've played for over an hour and it feels like nothing significant has really happened, so I guess what I'm trying to say is the game has been moving way too slowly for me... It feels like a knock off Stardew Valley and I felt as though the character customization didn't offer that much diversity. This one's just me nitpicking but I hate hate HATE when devs promote merchandise or other games as soon as I launch the game. I also felt as though there should be some sort of guide as to where buildings were located. Another thing that caused me some trouble was waiting for NPCs to show up so I could complete missions.

I will be trying out the game a little longer and update as I go.

That being said if you are able to sit down and play for a long time and like to run around figuring things out slowly, this might be the game for you.

Ughhhhhhh I got the sequel in a bundle recently so I figured I would try this one out again. See, when I first got the game, it had a *lot* of issues just even running... but that was back when it was a newer game. I had gotten it also in a bundle so it wasn't a huge deal to wait till the game was refined and my PC was upgraded. Thankfully, I don't have those original issues anymore. However, the game's pacing is absolutely awful.

First, the game's guidance is pretty abysmal. It is designed in a way where you either need to use a wiki, or *really* spend a lot of time exploring every area. This wouldn't be a huge issue if there was plenty of room for such a thing, except that...
Second, most of the game functions are time-locked. You don't get to choose when time sensitive events happen. And in many cases, you won't have enough hours in the day to do all the things expected of you. In some cases, you receive quests which you don't even have access to the resources yet. (Lookin' at you, Pinky the Devourer.)

Over it. Not sure I'mma try this one again.

I want to be clear: you *absolutely* can receive quests that you have *no way* to complete in the time allotted. Does it end the game? No. Is it stressful AF? Absolutely. A quest shouldn't trigger when *access to the required area* isn't possible and *the time needed to finish materials for the required quest are longer than the entire quest timer for the new quest*.
Bad design, and I do *not* have patience for it.
